Bartlett| doi = 10.1098/rsbm.1981.0017 | title = Egon Sharpe Pearson. 11 August 1895-12 June 1980 | journal = [[Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society]] | volume = 27 | pages = 425–426 | year = 1981 | jstor = 769879| pmid = | pmc = }} (11 August 1895 – 12 June 1980) was one of three children and the son of [[Karl Pearson]] and, like his father, a leading [[United Kingdom|British]] [[statistician]].{{MathGenealogy|id=29652}}{{MacTutor Biography|id=Pearson_Egon}} He went to [[Winchester School]] and [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], and succeeded his father as professor of statistics at [[University College London]] and as editor of the journal ''[[Biometrika]]''. Pearson is best known for development of the [[Neyman-Pearson lemma]] of statistical hypothesis testing. He was President of the [[Royal Statistical Society]] in 1955–56,{{cite web|url = http://www.rss.org.uk/site/cms/contentviewarticle.asp?article=486|title = Royal Statistical Society Presidents|publisher= Royal Statistical Society|accessdate = 6 August 2010}} and was awarded its [[Guy Medal]] in gold in 1955. He was awarded a CBE in 1946. He was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] in March 1966.{{cite web|url=http://royalsociety.org/uploadedFiles/Royal_Society_Content/about-us/fellowship/Fellows1660-2007.pdf|title=Lists of Royal Society Fellows 1660-2007|publisher=The Royal Society|accessdate=1 May 2011|location=London}} His candidacy citation read: "''Known throughout the world as co-author of the Neyman-Pearson theory of testing statistical hypotheses, and responsible for many important contributions to problems of statistical inference and methodology, especially in the development and use of the likelihood ratio criterion. Has played a leading role in furthering the applications of statistical methods — for example, in industry, and also during and since the war, in the assessment and testing of weapons.''" ==Works== * ''On the Use and Interpretation of certain Test Criteria for the Purposes of Statistical Inference'' (coauthor [[Jerzy Neyman]] in [[Biometrika]], 1928) * ''The History of statistics in the XVIIth and XVIIIth centuries'' (1929).
